com.apriori.testing

Interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The interface implemented by the class under test or Object if testing a class against more than one implemented interface
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfiguration<T>
    Enclosing class:
    InterfaceVerifier<T>

    public static interface InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T>
    Configures how one or more methods are executed and verified during interface verification.

    This interface uses a builder pattern. All methods return the MethodConfigurator to simplify usage and enhance readability through method chaining.

    Author:
    Joshua Humphries (jhumphries131@gmail.com)

    • Method Detail

      • mutator

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> mutator()
        Indicates that the method is a mutator method. The test and reference implementations will be verified after the method is called using the default mutator verifier.

        Note that if this method is called after a call to mutator(ObjectVerifier), the verifier will be changed from the previously specified verifier to the default verifier.

        Returns:
        this
        See Also:
        InterfaceVerifier.setDefaultMutatorVerifier(ObjectVerifier)

      • mutator

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> mutator(ObjectVerifier<? super T> v)
        Indicates that the method is a mutator method. The test and reference implementations will be verified after the method is called using the specified verifier.
        Parameters:
        v - The verifier to use to make sure the mutation in the test implementation is correct
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the argument is null

      • notMutator

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> notMutator()
        Indicates that the method is not a mutator method.
        Returns:

      • returnVerifier

        <R> InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> returnVerifier(ObjectVerifier<R> v,
                                                         Class<R> clazz)
        Specifies how to verify the return values after the method is called. This method takes a class token and verifies that it is compatible with the method's return type. This allows a runtime check during configuration before methods are invoked (which could cause ClassCastExceptions to be thrown later if the verifier is not compatible).
        Type Parameters:
        R - The return type of the method
        Parameters:
        v - The verifier used to verify the method return values
        clazz - A class token for the method's return type
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If this method's return type is void and the specified verifier is non-null or if the specified class is not compatible with the method's return type
        NullPointerException - If the specified class token is null

      • returnVerifier

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> returnVerifier(ObjectVerifier<?> v)
        Specifies how to verify the return values after the method is called.
        Parameters:
        v - The verifier used to verify the method return values
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If this method's return type is void and the specified verifier is non-null

      • strictExceptionVerifier

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> strictExceptionVerifier()
        Specifies that exceptions should be verified using strict checking. Exceptions thrown will be verified using ObjectVerifiers.STRICT_EXCEPTIONS.
        Returns:
        this

      • relaxedExceptionVerifier

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> relaxedExceptionVerifier()
        Specifies that exceptions should be verified using relaxed checking. Exceptions thrown will be verified using ObjectVerifiers.relaxedExceptions(Set), created with the method's declared (checked) exceptions and any unchecked exceptions defined (see uncheckedExceptions(Set).
        Returns:
        this

      • exceptionVerifier

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> exceptionVerifier(ObjectVerifier<Throwable> v)
        Specifies how to verify any exceptions thrown when a method is called. If a null verifier is specified then the method will use the default exception verifier (see InterfaceVerifier.getDefaultExceptionVerifier().
        Parameters:
        v - The verifier used to verify exceptions thrown in methods
        Returns:
        this

      • uncheckedExceptions

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> uncheckedExceptions(Class<? extends Throwable>... throwables)
        Indicates the set of unchecked exceptions thrown by a method.
        Parameters:
        throwables - The class tokens for the unchecked exception types
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any of the specified types are null
        See Also:
        uncheckedExceptions(Set)

      • uncheckedExceptions

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> uncheckedExceptions(Set<Class<? extends Throwable>> throwables)
        Indicates the set of unchecked exceptoins thrown by a method. These include RuntimeExceptions or Errors that could be thrown by a method that should be considered when verifying the exceptions thrown.
        Parameters:
        throwables - The set of class tokens for the unchecked exception types
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the specified set or any of the specified types therein are null

      • cloneAndVerifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> cloneAndVerifyArguments()
        Indicates that arguments should be cloned prior to method execution and then verified. This is appropriate for methods that mutate the incoming arguments. In this case, the arguments are cloned (so that mutations by the test implementation don't change the parameter to be passed to the reference implementation). After the method returns, the two argument objects are verified to make sure both implementations altered the arguments in the same way.

        This method will cause default implementations to be used for both cloning and verifying argument values. If you need to specify non-default implementations then use the other methods for explicitly setting cloners and verifiers. Note that you need to define the cloners before defining the verifiers.

        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If this method has no arguments that require cloning (i.e. all arguments are primitives) or has any arguments for which no appropriate default cloner exists
        See Also:
        cloneArguments(), verifyArguments()

      • cloneArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> cloneArguments()
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. A default implementation for cloning will be used to clone each argument.

        A single generic cloner will be used for cloning all arguments. The cloner used is Cloners.GENERIC_CLONER.

        If no verifiers are configured for the arguments then the arguments will not be verified -- only cloned prior to execution.

        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If this method has no arguments that require cloning (i.e. no arguments or all arguments are primitives) or if a default cloner cannot be created for any argument

      • cloneArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> cloneArgumentsWith(Cloner<?>... cloners)
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. The specified cloners will be used. The number of cloners provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null cloner means that argument does not need to be cloned. If an argument does not need to be cloned because it is a primitive but a non-null cloner is provided, an exception is thrown.
        Parameters:
        cloners - The sequence of argument cloners
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the number of cloners specified is not the same as the number of method arguments or if a non-null cloner is specified for an argument whose type is primitive

      • cloneArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> cloneArgumentsWith(List<Cloner<?>> cloners)
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. The specified cloners will be used. The number of cloners provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null cloner means that argument does not need to be cloned. If an argument does not need to be cloned because it is a primitive but a non-null cloner is provided, an exception is thrown.
        Parameters:
        cloners - The list of argument cloners
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the number of cloners specified is not the same as the number of method arguments or if a non-null cloner is specified for an argument whose type is primitive
        NullPointerException - If the specified list is null

      • cloneAllArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> cloneAllArgumentsWith(Cloner<?> cloner)
        Indicates that the arguments should be cloned prior to method execution. The specified cloner will be used for all arguments (except arguments that are primitive types).
        Parameters:
        cloner - The argument cloner
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If this method has no arguments that require cloning (i.e. no arguments or all arguments are primitives)
        NullPointerException - If the specified cloner is null

      • noCloneAndVerifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> noCloneAndVerifyArguments()
        Indicates that arguments should not be cloned prior to method execution, which implies that arguments do not need to be verified after execution.
        Returns:
        this

      • verifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> verifyArguments()
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The default verifier, ObjectVerifiers.EQUALS, will be used to verify the arguments.

        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If this method has no arguments that are to be cloned prior to execution

      • verifyArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> verifyArgumentsWith(ObjectVerifier<?>... verifiers)
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The specified verifiers will be used. The number of verifiers provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null verifier should be passed for arguments that are not cloned. If an argument is not cloned but a non-null verifier is provided, an exception is thrown.

        Parameters:
        verifiers - The sequence of verifiers
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the number of cloners specified is not the same as the number of method arguments or if a non-null verifier is provided for an argument that is not to be cloned prior to execution

      • verifyArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> verifyArgumentsWith(List<ObjectVerifier<?>> verifiers)
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The specified verifiers will be used. The number of verifiers provided must match the number of arguments for the method. A null verifier should be passed for arguments that are not cloned. If an argument is not cloned but a non-null verifier is provided, an exception is thrown.

        Parameters:
        verifiers - The list of verifiers
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the number of cloners specified is not the same as the number of method arguments or if a non-null verifier is provided for an argument that is not to be cloned prior to execution
        NullPointerException - If the specified list is null

      • verifyAllArgumentsWith

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> verifyAllArgumentsWith(ObjectVerifier<?> verifier)
        Indicates that the arguments should be verified after the method is executed. This is only useful in conjunction with cloning arguments since otherwise the two argument objects, the one passed to the test implementation and the one passed to the reference implementation, will be the same instance.

        The same verifier will be used for all cloned arguments.

        Parameters:
        verifier - The argument verifier
        Returns:
        this
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If this method has no arguments that are to be cloned prior to execution
        NullPointerException - If the specified verifier is null

      • noVerifyArguments

        InterfaceVerifier.MethodConfigurator<T> noVerifyArguments()
        Indicates that arguments do not need to be verified after execution. Note that arguments may still be cloned prior to execution. To prevent argument cloning, use noCloneAndVerifyArguments().
        Returns:
        this
